author: Drew Loftis
title: Fantasy football: Kaepernick’s descent will stop for one week
text:
If ever you needed to wish upon a falling star to make your fantasy come true, well, this is the week.
Few have fallen as steeply and rapidly, without the hardship of injury, as has 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick. It seems like just yesterday when he was among the ascending, next-generation stars — it feels like just yesterday because it practically was.
Just two seasons ago, he guided his team to the NFC Championship game. Just three seasons back, he took his squad to the brink of a Super Bowl victory. He was spoken of in the same breath as other young up-and-comers such as Russell Wilson, Andrew Luck and the mercurial Robert Griffin III.
As steep and rapid as Kaepernick’s decline has been, he hasn’t fallen as far or fast as has RG3. But at this rate, Kaepernick’s career is approaching terminal velocity.
So why would the Madman suggest you start someone trending so decidedly downward? You don’t bet against a streak, right?
Actually, that is exactly right, you don’t bet against a streak. And the streak the Madman will follow this week is the one the decrepit Ravens pass defense is riding.
In standard scoring leagues, Baltimore has given up 26 or more fantasy points to opposing QBs in three of its past four games — the lone exception being Mike Vick.
The Ravens were picked apart by Derek Carr. Yeah, but the Raiders do have some young talent on offense. They were ravaged by Andy Dalton. OK, the Bengals are a very good team. Then they were humiliated by Josh McCown. Josh McCown. I’m officially out of excuses.
Kaepernick doesn’t have to throw for 400-plus yards (like McCown) to be a good fantasy option. If you’re in a bind because of bye weeks or injury, he is a good streaming option.
In daily league formats, the outlook is even better. He is priced at the QB minimum on DraftKings ($5,000) — or the same as his backup, Blaine Gabbert. So you can get a starting QB going against a sieve of a pass defense for the same price as Bryce Petty — the Jets third-stringer.
Kaepernick’s $7,300 price tag at FanDuel makes him less of a bargain, but with what likely will be a low usage rate, investing in some roster coverage isn’t a bad idea.
Besides, sometimes, when you wish on a falling star, dreams can come true.
Big weeks Blake Bortles QB, Jaguars 
vs. Texans (DraftKings $5,200/FanDuel $7,300) 
Has been sneakily consistent over past four games (nine TDs, two INTs). Has two solid WRs to target in Allen Robinson and Allen Hurns, and he faces Houston D that puts no pressure on QBs.
Ronnie Hillman Photo: Getty Images Ronnie Hillman RB, Broncos 
at Browns (DK $4,600/FD $6,600) 
Hillman has done little to impress, but that’s still more than backfield mate C.J. Anderson. Browns have given up more rushing yards than any team.
Torrey Smith WR, 49ers 
vs. Ravens (DK $4,200/FD $6,200) 
Just like we expect a good game from Kaepernick, we anticipate residual fantasy numbers to flow toward Smith. Ravens have given up second-most fantasy points to WRs. Might get extra looks against his former team.
Jordan Cameron TE, Dolphins 
at Titans (DK $3,000/FD $5,400) 
Coming off a bye and coaching change, the Dolphins face a Tennessee team that has yielded some big games to TEs. Cheap price makes him valuable in daily formats.
Small weaks Josh McCown QB, Browns 
vs. Broncos (DK $5,400/FD $7,000) 
Expect his magical three-game ride to come to a sudden halt against a stiff Broncos defense. Denver is weaker defending against the ground attack, so more Duke Johnson Jr., less McCown.
Jonathan Stewart Photo: Getty Images Jonathan Stewart RB, Panthers 
at Seahawks (DK $3,900/FD $6,100) 
Has yet to top 62 yards in a game or reach the end zone — and that’s having faced three of the nine worst run defenses. Seattle has yielded the fewest fantasy points to opposing RBs.
Keenan Allen WR, Chargers 
at Packers (DK $7,600/FD $7,700) 
The Packers rank fourth in fewest fantasy points allowed to opposing WRs. Allen gets plenty of looks, but overall stats are warped by huge games against the Lions and Vikings.
Jimmy Graham TE, Seahawks 
vs. Panthers (DK $5,400/FD $6,300) 
Someone needs to tell the Seahawks this guy plays for them. Might not make much difference this week, against a Carolina team that has given up the fewest fantasy points to TEs, and gets back All-Pro LB Luke Kuechly.
